comments.text: so In general when you print this is it hollow? I want to stick a light on the inside and use clear filament so it looks lit up in green. also for someone who is better at building then me could someone create a separate base it can sit on? I want to add a phrase which I can do later if I have a base.
comments.author: pdeans

comments.text: The model is solid which means that it entirely depends on your printer settings. Most printers will leave the inside ~80% hollow so it would be quite easy to hollow it out from the bottom and stick a light inside :) Your printer settings will also control how thick the shell is and thus how bright the light will appear from the outside.

Ich verwende Inkscape https://inkscape.org/de/ mit dem JTech Laser Tool Plug-In
http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=2012 zum Erzeugen des GCodes.
Eine für den CTC/Flashforge modifizierte JTech Laser Tool Plug-In Version liegt
hier in den Thing Files.
Diese fuegt automatisch alle zusaetzlich noetigen GCode Aenderungen für den CTC ein.
Die Datei JTP_Laser_Tool_V1_6 cutting mod.zip im Inkscape Programmordner
C:\Program Files\Inkscape\share\extensions entpacken.
Als Inkscape Defaultkonfiguration fuer den Plotbereich die Datei CTC Default.svg
verwenden. Plotbereich 194x95mm. Konfiguration des Plug-Ins siehe Bild.
Der generierte GCode setzt unter anderem die X0 und Y0 Koordinaten nach unten/links.

Den Plug-In generierten GCode mit ReplicatorG oeffnen und X3G Datei generieren.
Fertig!

I use Inkscape https://inkscape.org/de/ with the Jtech Laser Tool Plug-In
http://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=2012 to generate the GCode.
A modified version for the CTC/FlashForge Jtech Laser Tool Plug-In is here in the Thing Files.
This automatically inserts all necessary additional GCode changes for the CTC.
Unpack the JTP_Laser_Tool_V1_6 cutting mod.zip in Inkscape program folder
C:\Program Files\Inkscape\share\extensions.
Use the CTC Default.svg file as Inkscape default configuration for the plot area.
Plot area 194x95mm. Configuration of the plug-ins see picture.
The generated GCode obliges it to X0 and Y0 coordinates down/left.

Open the plug-in generated GCode with ReplicatorG and generate X3G file.
Done!

comments.author: robscar

comments.text:
Ja, es passen die Silhouette Messer mit 14mm Durchmesser. Mit der Feder musst du experimentieren.
Es wird nur eine relativ niedrige Federspannung benoetigt. Das Messer sollte wegen der Schnittpraezision so
spielfrei wie moeglich in der Fuehrung laufen. Dies kann natuerlich je nach Drucker und Parametern variieren.
Das Bett muss nicht extra zum Plotten gelevelt werden. Ich drucke normal auf 4mm Glasplatte.
Es empfiehlt sich zum Schneiden statt der Glasplatte eine 4mm ABS Platte o.ae. einzusetzen oder
mindestens zum Schutz der Klinge ein extra Blatt Papier unter die zu schneidende Folie zu legen.

description.text:
My kids keep losing the remote controls to our Apple TVs. The thing is so small it falls into cracks, between couch cushions, under furniture, etc. After buying our third replacement remote I decided to end the madness and designed the Apple TV Remote Enlarge-Inator!

It's a case for the aluminum Apple TV remote that makes it larger so it is harder to lose.

20%

title: Star Trek Badge magnetic, with backing

description.text:
Available for purchase via http://etsy.me/1aMvmRQ
I adapted the tmorris9's high res trek badge with the following modifications:
  • changed magnet hole size to fit the standard small magnets i've been using (1/4" X 1/16")
  • added a backing plate to hold the other magnet, to keep it from being lost
  • raised the insignia higher so that it will work printing in two colors (pictured)

You can either print in yellow/gold and paint on silver, or change the filament over around layer 25 or so (watch it the first time, and adjust). Pictured, I changed from yellow to silver and it turned out great. Print the backing plate in any color.
You will need two magnets (1/4" X 1/16"). Use glue or acetone to affix the magnets.
Then call for a shuttlecraft or something!

description.text:
Video Demo : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tM8tXBGBS7w

UPDATE 05/24/16==================
Created a new handle for the rig, plus cable holder to keep the wire nice and neat to connect the button to the phone. Also updated the lens slider. Overall some improvement but still not happy with the handle, its not very comfortable to hold, plus the lens module is a pain to put together. So those two areas need some redesigning.

Here is the 3rd attempt at creating a custom beastgrip like rig that turns a phone into a camera. This attempt merged the ideas I had from MK1 and MK2 into a nice simple yet very modular design. Going back to an all threaded setup seemed like a better choice since it allows the parts to be very well tighten together to keep things from bouncing around compared to MK2's thumb screw tightening which is much more beastgrip like. Ideally once the rig is setup for a phone, there is no need to really adjust it, so making it tight makes it easier to just slap on the phone and get to work.

MK3, I was finally able to introduce the shutter button mechanics which is really the big selling point for me. MK1 and 2 was just not good enough so I never bothered, but mk3 is finally a very stable rig that I finally took it a step further with a shutter button. Its pretty easy to make one, just need a TRRS mount and a 200ohm resister between pole 4 and ground with the button allowing electricity to flow when you want to take a picture. What this does is tell the phone that you are pressing the up volume button which Vol Up/Down for camera apps trigger's the shutter.

Another feature is being able to creating the rig at what vertical length you need. For my rig i wanted it to be as small as possible BUT at the same time when I get a newer phone that might be bigger I can still adjust the height of the rig for it to fit. So by using through hole standoffs and long M3 screws, I am able to set the overall height of the rig. Length wise, I just bought 3 feet long threaded rods and cut them to the exact length I want the rig to be.

There are many ways to make the vertical rods. You can use long screws and short standoffs, or you can make the screws shorter but the standoffs longer. You can even use different types of standoffs. Another way is to use two screws with a coupler to hold them together. OR just buy a bunch of threaded rods for real cheap and cut to length exactly what you need and just use M3 nuts to tighten it to the 3d printed parts. So how to build it is up to you, depends on what you have at hand Or how you want it to kind of look like.

Needed Parts
Step-Down Adapter Ring 46mm Lens to 37mm (Needed to mount lenses)
http://amzn.to/1P5LpsJ

M3 Nuts
http://amzn.to/229gd8L

M3 Rods

Regular steel, very cheap and what I used on the prototype. With 50 cents a rod, you can pretty much just use this and a mini hacksaw or dremel to cut the lengths of both horizontal and vertical screws. I am also posting stronger grade rods if you want a more solid feel but it'll cost you a bit more.

https://www.zoro.com/value-brand-threaded-rod-steel-m3-05x3-ft-m203000301000/i/G9804453/

https://www.zoro.com/value-brand-threaded-rod-a2-ss-m3-05x1m-m510700301000/i/G9463072/

https://www.zoro.com/value-brand-threaded-rod-a4-ss-m3-05x3-ft-150794/i/G9051165/

Buttons
http://amzn.to/1Xlng7o
http://amzn.to/1Xlniwb
http://amzn.to/1Xlnz1V

4 Pole Coiled Headphone cable
http://www.ebay.com/itm/3ft-4-Pole-Spring-Coiled-3-5mm-Aux-Cable-w-Mic-Gold-Stereo-Audio-Auxiliary-Cord-/151917166186?hash=item235ef7fe6a:g:BXYAAOSwP~tW4zDW

TRRS Jack (I used an SMD i had, but you can probably use something else as long as its TRRS). Also just grab a 200ohm resister.
http://amzn.to/1XloHTm

Possible screws to use
M3 x 80mm screws
http://amzn.to/1pDCw4S

M3 x 70mm screws
http://amzn.to/1Xll5AT

M3 x 60mm screws
http://amzn.to/1Xllao4

Different Standoffs you can use

M3 x 6mm standoff
http://amzn.to/1P5Leh1

http://amzn.to/1XllByL

http://amzn.to/1P5LD33

title: Dropping Eggs From Drones for Science and Fun UPGRADED
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was invited to participated Fort Wort Academy's Egg-Drop event again this year. Since there was a problem with eggs getting stuck in the cups last year I decided to revisit the design and make some improvements. With the rig from last year to fall back on I had very little pressure from a clock. I'd experimented with OpenSCAD here and there but this was an opportunity to work a complicated design in the software. In the end I set up one file with my parameters and definitions and "imported" and "include" several .scad files for pins (Thanks emmett!) and the servo arm fitting (Thanks again hugokernel!)

The only object that wasn't generated natively in SCAD was the Iris mounting bracket. I downloaded Ferdinand128's beautifully finished STL and tweaked it for the pins in SCAD before exporting the modified version.

I had to make several separate .scad files for separate components due to complexity and the capabilities of OpenSCAD. I combined the exported STL files into a single SCAD file for visual checks of the final assembly prior to printing. While I had them combined in the final assembly I went ahead and animated it because why not? (What do you know, thingiverse doesn't like animated .gifs)

I'll upload more pictures and videos after the event.

I printed several tests in PLA from my scrap built Prusa i3 but the final print was done in ABS at the Dallas Maker Space (@dallasmakers). We ran into a warping problem last year after the PLA rig sat in a hot car long enough for the bolts and screws to deform the rig enough that it had to be reprinted.

Once printed all parts use pins to snap in place. The only screws will be to hold the servo arm to the servo, the servo to the top frame and the mounting bracket to the Iris Plus. I had expected to have to use acetone or friction welding on the pins just to be sure everything was solid but after it was assembled it felt strong enough without. If it does fall apart at the even it can simply be snapped back together and welded later.

comments.text: FYI, I don't think this is legal in the USA.
comments.author: pcnate

comments.text: I believe we will be within the FAA regulations. The drone is registered, under 55lbs, will be flown below 400' and within line of sight, and not within 5 miles of an airport or stadium. We also have lots of other rules we set about approaching the drone only when given permission by the pilot (powered off) and that it will never fly over any bodies head in case of an "uncontrolled descent event." (AKA "crash") If there are other regulations that this would violate please let me know. We will comply if possible and cancel if not.
comments.author: pcnate

comments.text: Thanks for sharing this! I've been super frustrated by the fixed idler on the Raise3D N2. It's a huge relief to be back to spring-loaded.

comments.text: You're very welcome.  Mine has been working well and it's been over a year now so the printed part should hold up OK for you.  I never got around to machining it out of metal, but it doesn't look like I have to.  Raise3D came by to visit me the other day and they liked the mod when they saw it.

print_settings.Resolution:: I used a 0.4 nozzle and 0.3 layer height

title: ZMR QAV Eachine Racer 250 Antenna holder for Redcon CM621 receiver

description.text:
Edit 5/5/16 Added configuration that uses 2.5 mm straws to support antenna. Some brands of cotton swabs sold in the U.S.A. use a yellow tube holding the swabs. Cut to the right length, insert the antenna, and then the tube into the frame and you are ready to go.
Add drop of non-permanent glue as required.

This is a receiver/antenna holder for the Redcon CM621 DSM2 receiver sold at Banggood.com and others.
http://www.banggood.com/REDCON-2_4G-6CH-Microlite-DSM2-Full-Range-Receiver-CM621-p-1007463.html

This thing provides a holder for the receiver and guides to hold the antennas at a 45 degree angle. The CM621 is a lightweight, bargain priced, 6 channel PWM DSM2 receiver that is suitable for many vehicles.

I pushed the antennas into the grooves and put a piece of masking tape around the each support to hold it in place. I attach the receiver to the holder with a rubber band, and use a couple pieces of Velcro under the connector pins and at the end of the holder to fasten it to the vehicle. Neither is very sophisticated, but they work. The receiver is longer than the holder. I let the pins hang out the back end.
It takes less than 800 mm of 1.75 filament for this thing.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used a 0.4 nozzle and 0.3 layer height

Notes:

I have printed earlier versions in PLA and ABS. ABS takes more cleanup in the antenna grooves; it may work better if printed slower or at a lower temperature.
This can be printed with or without infill. The antenna holders are not filled in w/o infill, but it saves a bit of weight and is still strong enough. It's probably best if the antenna holders break during a crash. Maybe the receiver will survive better.
You will probably need a file to square up the edges of the receiver tray and open up the grooves for the antenna wires.
The sketchup file is attached.

title: Dishwasher Clean/Dirty Sliding Sign
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Laser cut Clean/Dirty sign.

Black lines are first pass engraving.
Blue lines are second pass cut.
Red lines are third pass cut.

Top rectangle is the bottom of the sign sandwich. Circular cut-outs are for recessed magnets.

Middle rectangle is the center of the frame and sliding puck. Lightly sand back and long edges of puck for easy sliding. Glue wooden bead to Right-Center of puck to allow you to slide puck left and right.

Bottom rectangle is the signs top.

comments.text: Cool that you have an arduino under the hood. How does it fly for you?
comments.author: slingshots-1

comments.text: It flew OK, but it is a right on the edge of too much for the arduino to handle. Being the 8 bit 16 MHz "speed-demon" it is I was never able to iron out all of the shakes and wiggles. I switched it over to a newer purpose built board the "Naze32" which flys better than the old setup straight out of the box. This was my first attempt at flying quads and it was a fun experiment and I learned a lot. I used multiwii 2.4 firmware on a stock arduino with a separate little 6-axis gyro board foam taped on. LOL  Original goal was to use the cheapest parts available to get into the hobby. I have flown RC airplanes and heli's for years and this looked like a blast.

author: escu_12

description.text:
This is the motor mount firewall for the FliteTest Sparrow foam board plane. The instructions for the build are to cut this out of Ply so I modeled one for 3D printing. I have added a small cutout for the button to give space for wires, and I have also added a lip to aid alignment within the box, I would advise only to glue the outer face (not the lip) as removal of the firewall can then be done by slicing through the glue, if you glue the lip too then removing the firewall will be tricky should you need to change motor etc.

13XX, 18XX and 22XX versions available. Should fit all 1306, 1806, 2206 motors.

The 22XX version has no lip due to the limited space for bolts.

Foot for Tektronix 465 oscilloscope (as well as other models).

I designed this as a temporary measure to stop my scope with a missing foot from wobbling.

I plan to add the little bumps to hold the power cable in place. Ideally needs to be printed with a tough material as it has to take the weight of the scope.

comments.text: You would do well to make the counterbore as shallow as possible and use a longer screw. Otherwise the wall thickness of the counterbore is thin. The parts made by Tek occasionally fail when the cord tension collapses the wall. I've had the same problem in parts I've molded myself.

Remember the candlestick silhouette optical illusion?  I drew this up for a friend before realizing it would have to print for 80 hours...
A little bit AutoCAD, a little bit VisualCAD.  Shaken, not stirred.

Click on "YES" above to see a picture.

All you need to use it is a usual cheap ball pen refill, or use one from a free advertisement pen. :)

Can be printed without any support and even without object cooling.

I've printed mine in 0,3mm layer height, with raft, 3 top/bottom/outline layers, 15% fast honeycomb infill, cheap PETG filament made by "Real" (RepRapWorld.com, EU) and it is extremly stable, can't be broken with bare hands.

Printing Time ~1:30h with my Zonestar Prusa I3

EDIT: I've added a pen-holder but it's alpha version and I haven't printed it yet

author: watsdesign

title: Limit Switch / Endstop Mount For OrdBot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This was only temporary until i found the proper screws to use with the ord bot chassis I did a transplant from a printrbot to an ordbot (something about all wood to all metal seemed like a great idea) and I needed a way to mount the included micro limit switches for all my axis' on the siderails. This is my solution, it mounts on the makerslide using one m4 screw, Allowing the end nuts of the v-roller wheels to hit the switch. Note: Because the way the switch has to be lined up in order to be triggered you may lose a few mm of bed space, I measured about 8.5mm of lost print surface from my x and y axis'

Print off three of these and the vitamins are: -3x 5mm(atleast) m4 screw (found mine at lowes in the metric screw drawers)
-3x makerslide m4 tslot nut (I received 6 from my reprapdiscount kit)
-6x 12mm m3 screws (for the microswitch you may need to drill bigger mounting holes into your switch, be sure to hold them down well from top to bottom or you will rip them open) Note: The orientation of the switch doesn't matter but it does depend on the sensitivity of the switch, so place it the way it will work.

author: 3DPingu

print_settings.Notes:: max. 15mm/s

description.text:
####
Dieser Knopf ist kompatibel zur Sennheiser G3 Serie. Ich warne direkt vor: der Druck kann sehr frustrierend sein ;) Wichtig ist, dass der Knopf auf dem Kopf gedruckt wird, damit der kleine Pin in der Mitte entstehen kann. Dieser betätigt letztendlich den Taster am PCB. Wenn er nicht vorhanden ist, drückt der Rand mit auf den Taster und ihr bekommt das Mikrofon nicht an! Der Knopf funktioniert ohne den Ring, welcher aber wenn aus flexiblem Filament gedruckt werden muss, hat aber mit einen angenehmeren Druckpunkt. Ganz wichtig: in der Ruhe liegt die Kraft - ich empfehle nicht mehr als 15mm/s.

####
Ok guys, you're now able to replace Sennheiser's G3 power button for just a few bucks, providing that your printer is able to print out this filigran piece of plastic ;) You need to print it upside down, cause the little pin in the middle is doing all the work later on. If you don't have it, you won't be able to turn on your mic. The provided distance ring gives you a better pressure point, although you don't need it. But if you're going to print it out, make sure you're using flexible filament. I recommend a maximum speed of 15mm/s.

title: Flite Test FT Mighty Mini Arrow Fuselage

description.text:
I built my first FT Arrow and loved it. It is a great plane and a lot of fun. However, I had issues with batteries, overall toughness, and the power pod constantly shoving itself too deep in the fuselage resulting in the prop rubbing. The plane was designed around an 800mah 3S battery, but all of my 3S's are 1300 or larger. My smallest one is a 1000mah 4S, which is essentially the same size. Anyway, many good crashes with too much weight in a fuselage that was overstuffed, resulted in my first Arrow splitting down the middle from the stress. Time to design an alternative! My goals were to create a tougher, one-piece design, that would allow those precious few extra millimeters of battery space, while providing better motor and component mounting. I came up with the attached design in my head, but I have no skill with CAD programs, so my buddy Henry aka RomulanAle here on Thingiverse did the drawing work for me. I told him exactly what I was looking for, and together we came up with this awesome part!

Pros:
-one piece with solid mounted firewall
-no mods to the rest of the plane
-firewall has standard "full size" 16x19 mount holes for 220X motors
-"mesh" design allows great electronics cooling, while giving tons of options for zip-tieing components
-space for batteries up to 2200mah (I plan to use 1300 3S)
-still plenty of surface area to glue or tape the top of the wing
-better protection for FPV camera in a head-on crash

Cons:
-no longer swappable
-if you use too much hot glue in the build you'll make a mess on your electronics
-a few cents worth of printer plastic is still more expensive than foam board

***Take care when mounting your motor... depending on how your shaft protrudes out the bottom, you may have to trim the center hole slightly. I designed it around a Cobra 2204, but I ended up having to trim with a hobby knife to allow the C clip on the Emax 2204 shown in the pics to spin freely. Enjoy, and have fun!!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Folgertech Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

No

.2 mm layers

20%

Notes:

I used PLA, but I'm sure other materials would work fine. My printer has a 200x200mm platform, and the fuse is exactly 200mm long. I placed it top down diagonally across my bed, and it printed with no problems.

comments.author: catarina

comments.text: As a solid, ABS poses no danger. I'm no expert, but these chemicals are probably stable because they are part of the plastic matrix. I would think a certain temperature needs to be achieved to release the hazardous chemicals. Clearly, more research needs to be done, but I think it's safe in hot water. On the other hand, I would definitely try to vent the fumes when priniting.

author: ssimms

description.text:
UPDATE: V2 constructed small notches into the hinges - now even the heaviest cell phones should be safe in any angle.

Yes, yet another Smartphone Dock!

All the other docks for a the new Galaxy Edge Series either dont fit right or just big blobs of plastic, so I created my own version, trying to extend the design of the Edge Series. Gravity and the usb cable will hold the Smartphone in place. The caddy is also curved so the finger print sensor can be swiped without problems.

Also my Dock is adjustable in the angle and can also get very small in case you want to take it with you on a business trip or vacation.

Also the basic design is very simple - just install the usb cable and click the caddy into the dock. the two covers also lock the cable and the connector into place.

Suggestions

I printed the Dock and the Caddy in PLA and the baseplate and backcover in FilaFlex.

Assembly

Insert the USB-Cable first into the Dock then into the Caddy. Click the Caddy into the Dock and add the baseplate and the backcover.

The friction between the hinges is enough to hold the Caddy in every angle - if your Smartphone is heavy and the friction isnt enough just use some sand paper to roughen up the hinges.

remixed_from.author: iamburny
remixed_from.title: RepRap Pro Ormerod iamburnys Z Gears - Parametric - Double Helix - Herringbone

description.text:
Amsterdam's Remix was nice, but didn't produce a tight enough fit for my Z stepper motor.

I've revised the OpenSCAD code borrowing lines from DC42's mix of Iamburney's extruder gears, to produce some that fit my printer.

The original Iamburney's Z stepper gear works as normal, but i've flipped the nut cavity over to the bearing side, and decreased the hole that the M5 rod goes through, to help it line up centrally.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Ormerod

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

At least two perimeters, and three top shells for a nice surface.

I print with the first layer 210 Nozzle, and then subsequent at 200. With the bed set to 65 constantly.

Getting the fit

These should require no post-processing, however if it's too tight, then heating up the nut, or stepper shaft with a soldering iron should allow the part to be wedged on.

comments.text: You should either provide the gears separately or leave at least a gap between them. I am not sure if all Slicers can separate them (my Slicer can).

title: Electric flute
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It tries to resemble a traditional recorder flute by having 7 "holes" over it and one under it. The holes are actually covered by thin copper pieces which work as capacitive sensors. I recommend using cut copper nails of good size, even though the photos at the moment have only bare wires in a spiral shape. The mouth piece has no acoustic properties and simply directs the air flow to a air flow sensor component MPXV7002DP. The outward facing tip has tray where Arduino Nano can be slided in after the wires have been soldered. The cap keeps it in place and USB cable can be connected through it. There is also extra room to take out a thin cable if you want the serial TX to also work with real MIDI port.

The firmware is on Github which acts as a serial midi device and sends notes for a synthesizer when a proper finger combination is detected along some noticeable air flow. The "power" of the air flow adjusts the velocity.

Assembling and printing tips:
There is an extra hole for passing through the air flow sensor wires and it would be a good idea to apply some hot glue to it after passing the wires so that it is air tight.
The upward positioned model is good for printing but cabling can be tricky. For that purpose I made horizontally modelled model of two halves which makes that a lot easier, but I have not yet tried to print it and it needs glueing after cabling. I recommend using the upwards positioned model.

Arduino firmware:
https://github.com/jsalin/eflute

comments.text: Added a mouth piece for blowing air through a hole while holding the pipe sideways (like a flute, unlike a recorder). The software is working very well by now and I'm considering this project finished.

comments.text: I've not yet been able to print one of these, either on my Solidoodle or my Flashforge.  One or more of the turbine blades keeps breaking off mid-print.  Any suggestions?
comments.author: Caboose28

comments.text: How far up does it get before breaking?
comments.author: Caboose28

comments.text: Roughly three inches.  The blades basically get drug around by the nozzle.  I'm using PETG currently, .1mm resolution, 240c with a 60c bed.
comments.author: renniuq

comments.text: The strength of the blades before they are joined up is quite low, perhaps they are breaking as the nozzle drags across the surface. Perhaps try dropping the bed 50 microns between extrusion areas. Alternatively, perhaps PLA or ABS would print better.
comments.author: Caboose28

comments.text: I've printed it with PETG and PLA.  I don't really have any ABS, never had much luck with it.  What I'm going to try is printing it upside down with support and see how that turns out, since the middle isn't really visible.  Also, I had it set up for 1mm Z-axis drop between nozzle movements.

comments.text: On the wobble issue, as long as your joints are tight (a big if), the stiffness of the square part is related to the third power of beam depth in the direction paralell to the load, linear with respect to the width of the beam, and linear with respect to the modulus of elasticity of the beam material, all other things being constant. Stiffness is proportional to E*I

This is a flash diffuser for a Canon Speedlite 580EXII It may fit other Flash units the dimensions for the head are 76mm x 49mm. It works great when using it as a bounce flash and the diffuser adds a fill flash, you get two flashes in one.

You can print in low with 10% fill needs supports no raft and add 4 helper tabs placed equally spaced out on the ring.
I changed my filament at 80 mm to get the black base. You will see it start to print the tabs in the supports that is about 80 mm. Must use clear filament to work as a diffuser!

description.text:
Ok, so I got a new spool of filament which has fins inside the spool's center, so my previous spoolholder couldn't handle it.

So I made a new one, it's basicly same as the old one but instead of of those pins, this has only a hole for a bolt.

And then I turned it into a customizable thing, this one can spawn the older pin-type holders as well as the new one I needed myself.

A work in progress as I try to figure out how that customizer works.
Edit: I made some changes, lets see how it works now in the customizer. Is it better to get a single STL or all 3 at same time? Is it confusing to get STL's for parts you dont need? I tried to make it so that it would give you only the hole type if it was selected or both the left and right sides if either of them were selected, but I couldn't make that work.

description.text: Another cookie cutter for the set.

Printer:

DaVinci 2.0A Duo

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

90 (full)

Notes:

I've printed it with 90fill (full), slow speed, 0.2 stepsize, normal wall-thickness and model slices in the XYZware with these settings. Note that slicing should give you a double-wall with no holes.

Done in Blender 2.76 by manually drawing the shape based on a bitmap and using extrude and solidify-modifier plus mesh-cleanup steps.

Sliced in XYZware giving double-walls without holes.

The ZIP file contains the STL file, but also the resulting 3w file and the original Blender file for modification.

Blender Details
•Start with scene, delete default object (in Edit mode)
•Add "shape" bitmap in Z-projection (optional)
•Create vertex loop (CTRL clicking), closed
•Scale such, that 10 Blender units represent 10mm
•clean-up loop (add/remove vertices), smooth etc.
•Duplicate object (in Object mode) to have one for "upper" and one for "lower" part.
•Extrude (in Edit mode) lower part 3 units downwards
•Ensure face-normals point outward (Recompute normals if needed)
•In Object mode, apply "Solidify modifier", no offset, thickness 0.3-0.7
•Extrude (in Edit mode) upper part 10 units upwards
•Ensure face-normals point outward (Recompute normals if needed)
•In Object mode, apply "Solidify modifier", no offset, thickness 0.07-0.2
•In Object mode, select both parts, then File/Export as STL

Solidify modifier thickness might need adjustment (0.09 to 0.15) depending on how the slicer creates the walls. It should create a double-wall with no gaps!

title: HeadPlay HD FPV Headset Battery Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yet another battery holder for the awesome HeadPlay FPV Goggles.

The idea came to me when I had some issues with the battery and the supplied velcro, I felt that it could easily be improved. Especially with the GoPro mount available. I thought that there must already be some kind of solutions available on Thingiverse and there was (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1150824 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1133100) I liked them but I thought they were not fully using the potential of the GoPro mount. After a few prototypes I came up with this quite simple solution.

When the battery is placed in the battery holder it can be securely folded against the backplate of the straps. Tighten the bolt firmly but not to hard and you will be able to open and close without adjusting the bolt.

Any resolution and infill will work, but I recommend that you have at least 40% or more infill otherwise there is a slight risk that it breaks when removing the battery(if you have tightened the bolt to much).

Any suggestions or for a updated version don't hesitate to contact me.

If you don't have access to a 3D printer I can print you one for a small fee

3D Printer
To print the unicorn horn, the 3D printer will need to be capable of printing a minimum of 140mm tall. The diameter of the horn is 40mm x 48mm, which should be enough to fit on most beds, such as the Printrbot Simple Metal.
For 3D printing with Ninjaflex material, we recommend using a printer with a direct direct, spring loaded extruder. The horn can be printed in PLA, ABS and other filaments.
Slicer Settings
For the best quality when printing with NinjaFlex, we recommend the following slicing settings:
Retraction: Off
Speeds: 90/150
Extruder Temp: 230c
Infill 10%
Raft+Support: Off
No Heated Bed
Print time is approximately 3 hours.

Print 4 or more and snap on the lower threaded rods that run parallel to the X-axis.  Optional:  Stick on some rubber pads to keep from sliding.

Here is my third version of a costume prop for Tom Clancy's The Division video game. It's some kind of shoulder beacon / gizmo that all the characters wear. I'm not really sure what it does in the game, but if you're making a costume for The Division, you'll need one. Version 3 is longer, and adds buttons on the left side, texture on the back, socket head cap screw pockets on the top, as well as some other changes.

  • The internals are basically 1/2 the parts in a NeoPixel Goggle kit (Google it). My custom code is posted in the files. Follow the NeoPixel Goggle Kit tutorial on Adafruit's site, and use my code.
  • The flexible portion of the antenna is a piece cut from a small tape measure, then dipped in Plasti Dip tool handle coating (fill a 3/4" PVC pipe with it, so that you can dip the whole length with several coats).
  • To connect the antenna portion to the body, bend a section of #10-32TPI threaded rod into a "U" shape. You'll probably need to heat it with a torch, or it will break instead of bending.
  • The screws in the top are #6-32 and #2-56 SHCS, which you can buy at McMaster-Carr.
  • Attach some sort of clip to the back plate. I epoxied one of these on... http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00DUXL7W4

Here's a video of the previous version.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PwMSWwzUPG0

Enjoy! Please Like it. If you make one or have improvements, please post.

comments.text: How long do the cap screws need to be for the top?
comments.author: Crossfire0mega

comments.text: Pretty much any length, because they are decorative only.  They don't actually bolt into anything... you just epoxy them in place.  So as long as they are long enough to glue, and short enough to not run into stuff sticking out the bottom, you're good.  If you look at the files of the ones I used, the length is written right in the file name, and the part number is from McMaster-Carr (so you can look them up and order them).

comments.text: Solidworks, by default, exports STL files in cm instead mm. If you scale it up by a factor of 10, then everything should be right.
comments.author: kanetreble

comments.text: Not necessarily.  SolidWorks outputs in whatever units are selected (e.g. Inch Pounds Seconds - IPS, Millimeter Gram Seconds - MMGS, Centimeter Gram Seconds - CGS, etc.), or what you override them to.  There is really no "default" as its a per file, and per user, setting.
comments.author: raveious

comments.text: Weird, they opened and printed fine for me.  I'll have to get the exact size, but it should be about 5" long.  Are you sure it didn't open in millimeters, but the file is in inches (e.g. scale it 25.4x bigger to get it to inches)?  That's the most common problem.

comments.author: guido666

comments.text: So they aren't "scaled wrong", you just aren't loading them in the scale they are drawn in (e.g. inches vs. mm).  Ideally, you should not open them then scale... instead just tell it that they are in inches/mm when you open them.

Making hexaflexagons is a popular past time with my kids - so who would have thought that a hexaflexagon could be designed and printed in 3D. Well, it turns out it can, and it works just like the paper ones, only with a pleasing feel in the hands, strangely like prayer beads, once you start you can't put it down - enjoy! If you are not familior with the joys of hexaflexagation, here is Viheart's video on the subject http://youtu.be/VIVIegSt81k

The hinges are printed in place, so you need a properly calibrated printer. Only the outer hinge needs to be snap-fitted together. The folding pattern is quite tricky, but look at the photos and use the symbols as a guide. They should all be facing up, but I'm sure you figured that out! This is best printed with multiple colours using the Sailfish [email protected] function. With the default tri_height, pause the print at 1mm and 5 mm (for customised versions, that is 1 mm and tri_height - 1mm).

comments.text: I printed this, and the hinges were solid and the triangle segments didn't have visible space between. I tried bending it at a hinge, but the hinge broke right off. I changed the scad to use a 0.4mm tolerance instead of 0.2, and when I printed that, I could see the spacing between each triangle segment, but the hinge mechanics were so tight that they cone part broke off when I forced the segments to bend. Strange, because I have another part (openscad) with a 0.2mm tolerance that fits really nicely, but on this part a 0.4mm tolerance is still stuck.  I'll play with it a bit more, perhaps try one of the remixes.

comments.author: deanthinker

comments.text: So first of all, drop the print temperature - 225-230 should be adequate. Next make sure you are specifying you exact filament diameter, either in a custom profile in Makerware http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38390http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... profile or by use ReplicatorG http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:80728http://www.thingiverse.com/thi..., Slic3r or Kisslicer. I can't stress this enough, if your printer is putting out too much plastic, the hinges will stick together. Even if you don't have a set of digital callipers to measure you filament, try increasing the filament size by 0.05mm, and if that isn't enough then by 0.1 - that should fix it.

description.text: I really like emmett's Minimalistic Mk8 replacement, but I found that the idler tended to fail under pressure after a couple of months, and fitting the spring in was pretty difficult sometimes. So, for this I gave the idler more support and made the spring stays a bit rounder. While I was at it I also simplified the bearing mount's support to make it easier to clean out.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

100%

Per the original:

You'll need a 693 or 623 bearing and a 3x10mm bolt for each extruder. Print these at 100% infill with zero extra shells. Rip the support out of the notch in the arm. Put the bearing in there and keep in place by screwing in the bolt (from the back, as in the head will face the motor).

Disassemble the fan/heatsink and remove the old extruder. Use the same mounting bolts to attach the two pieces of the minimal Mk8 extruder. Make it nice and tight and reassemble the fan and heatsink the same way. Cram a spring into the notches between the two arms. I used the same spring I used on the original minimal Mk7, which in my case was Utility Comp Spring C-614 (5/16 x 1-1/4 x 0.041 inches) I found at my local hardware store.

I find it easier to insert the spring if you remove the drive gear first.
